In this work, we investigate the effective memory span of transformer-based world models through an analysis of several memory augmentation mechanisms. We introduce a taxonomy that distinguishes between memory encoding and memory injection mechanisms, motivating their roles in extending the world model's memory through the lens of residual stream dynamics. Using a state recall evaluation task, we measure the memory recall of each mechanism and analyze its respective trade-offs. Our findings show that memory mechanisms improve the effective memory span in vision transformers and provide a path to completing loop closures within a world model's imagination.

item.title: Utilizing Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning with Encoder-Decoder Architecture Agents to Identify Optimal Resection Location in Glioblastoma Multiforme Patients
item.content:encoded:
Glioblastoma Multiforme, AI diagnosis, Treatment planning, Reinforcement learning, Survival rate optimization

Summary:

This project addresses the lack of AI tools for managing heterogeneous brain tumors like Glioblastoma Multiforme (GBM), aiming to assist doctors in both diagnosis and treatment planning. First, a sequential decision-making framework employing four classification models, including Convolutional Neural Networks and Support Vector Machines, progressively refines patient brain tumor classification for accurate diagnosis. Second, the treatment planning phase uses a reinforcement learning system composed of three generative models: a diffusion model predicting possible surgical resection outcomes, a Spatio-Temporal Vision Transformer forecasting tumor progression post-radiotherapy, and another diffusion model simulating post-chemotherapy MRI results. Third, a survival rate calculator CNN evaluates if the generated post-treatment MRI meets user-defined survival targets within a 15% threshold. If not, a proximal policy optimization feedback loop iteratively refines treatment parameters to identify optimal resection strategies. Key findings include a 22.28-fold reduction in computing costs using the sequential diagnostic framework, a 113-hour decrease in tumor progression inference time enabled by transformer regression models, and a 2.9% improvement in DICE scores from realistic data augmentations. Collectively, these innovations could enhance survival rates by 0.9%, potentially saving around 2,250 lives.
arXiv:2512.06990v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Currently, there is a noticeable lack of AI in the medical field to support doctors in treating heterogenous brain tumors such as Glioblastoma Multiforme (GBM), the deadliest human cancer in the world with a five-year survival rate of just 5.1%. This project develops an AI system offering the only end-to-end solution by aiding doctors with both diagnosis and treatment planning. In the diagnosis phase, a sequential decision-making framework consisting of 4 classification models (Convolutional Neural Networks and Support Vector Machine) are used. Each model progressively classifies the patient's brain into increasingly specific categories, with the final step being named diagnosis. For treatment planning, an RL system consisting of 3 generative models is used. First, the resection model (diffusion model) analyzes the diagnosed GBM MRI and predicts a possible resection outcome. Second, the radiotherapy model (Spatio-Temporal Vision Transformer) generates an MRI of the brain's progression after a user-defined number of weeks. Third, the chemotherapy model (Diffusion Model) produces the post-treatment MRI. A survival rate calculator (Convolutional Neural Network) then checks if the generated post treatment MRI has a survival rate within 15% of the user defined target. If not, a feedback loop using proximal policy optimization iterates over this system until an optimal resection location is identified. When compared to existing solutions, this project found 3 key findings: (1) Using a sequential decision-making framework consisting of 4 small diagnostic models reduced computing costs by 22.28x, (2) Transformers regression capabilities decreased tumor progression inference time by 113 hours, and (3) Applying Augmentations resembling Real-life situations improved overall DICE scores by 2.9%. These results project to increase survival rates by 0.9%, potentially saving approximately 2,250 lives.

item.title: ClinNoteAgents: An LLM Multi-Agent System for Predicting and Interpreting Heart Failure 30-Day Readmission from Clinical Notes
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Heart failure, clinical notes, readmission prediction, large language model, risk factors

Summary: Heart failure (HF) is a major cause of rehospitalization among older adults in the US, and clinical notes in electronic health records (EHRs) contain valuable patient information that is usually underutilized for predicting HF readmission risk. Traditional models depend heavily on expert-crafted rules, medical thesauri, and ontologies, which struggle with clinical notes' informal language, abbreviations, and misspellings. The study introduces ClinNoteAgents, a multi-agent framework powered by large language models (LLMs), designed to convert free-text clinical notes into structured data representing clinical and social risk factors and clinician-style summaries for 30-day HF readmission prediction. Evaluated on 3,544 notes from 2,065 patients with a readmission rate of 35.16%, ClinNoteAgents demonstrated strong capabilities in extracting relevant risk factors, highlighting key contributing elements, and accurately predicting readmission risk. This approach reduces dependency on structured EHR fields, lowers the need for manual annotation and model training, and offers a scalable, interpretable solution suitable for healthcare systems with limited data resources. Overall, ClinNoteAgents represents an innovative use of LLMs for improving HF readmission risk modeling through effective utilization of unstructured clinical text.
arXiv:2512.07081v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Heart failure (HF) is one of the leading causes of rehospitalization among older adults in the United States. Although clinical notes contain rich, detailed patient information and make up a large portion of electronic health records (EHRs), they remain underutilized for HF readmission risk analysis. Traditional computational models for HF readmission often rely on expert-crafted rules, medical thesauri, and ontologies to interpret clinical notes, which are typically written under time pressure and may contain misspellings, abbreviations, and domain-specific jargon. We present ClinNoteAgents, an LLM-based multi-agent framework that transforms free-text clinical notes into (1) structured representations of clinical and social risk factors for association analysis and (2) clinician-style abstractions for HF 30-day readmission prediction. We evaluate ClinNoteAgents on 3,544 notes from 2,065 patients (readmission rate=35.16%), demonstrating strong performance in extracting risk factors from free-text, identifying key contributing factors, and predicting readmission risk. By reducing reliance on structured fields and minimizing manual annotation and model training, ClinNoteAgents provides a scalable and interpretable approach to note-based HF readmission risk modeling in data-limited healthcare systems.

item.title: VIGIL: A Reflective Runtime for Self-Healing Agents
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Agentic LLM, runtime introspection, VIGIL, autonomous maintenance, self-repair

Summary:

1. This paper addresses the limitations of current agentic Large Language Model (LLM) frameworks, which often struggle with brittleness, lack of runtime introspection, and inability to self-diagnose or improve autonomously over time.
2. Many deployed agent stacks degenerate into simple chains of LLM calls without structural methods to ensure reliability and robustness during task execution.
3. The authors propose VIGIL (Verifiable Inspection and Guarded Iterative Learning), a reflective runtime system designed to supervise and maintain a sibling agent rather than directly execute tasks.
4. VIGIL processes behavioral logs, converts events into structured emotional representations stored in an EmoBank with decay and context-aware policies, and generates RBT (Reflective Behavior Tree) diagnoses categorizing recent behaviors into strengths, opportunities, and failures.
5. Based on this analysis, VIGIL produces guarded prompt updates that preserve the agent’s core identity and read-only code proposals created by a strategy engine focused on log evidence and code hotspots.
6. The system employs a state-gated pipeline that enforces legal transitions, preventing LLM improvisation and ensuring error transparency.
7. In practical case studies like reminder latency, VIGIL successfully detected issues, proposed fixes, and demonstrated meta-level self-repair by surfacing internal errors, generating fallback diagnoses, and producing repair plans autonomously.
8. These innovations showcase how VIGIL advances agent runtime reliability through introspection, autonomous diagnosis, and iterative maintenance, enhancing long-term agent performance without human intervention.
arXiv:2512.07094v2 Announce Type: new Abstract: Agentic LLM frameworks promise autonomous behavior via task decomposition, tool use, and iterative planning, but most deployed systems remain brittle. They lack runtime introspection, cannot diagnose their own failure modes, and do not improve over time without human intervention. In practice, many agent stacks degrade into decorated chains of LLM calls with no structural mechanisms for reliability. We present VIGIL (Verifiable Inspection and Guarded Iterative Learning), a reflective runtime that supervises a sibling agent and performs autonomous maintenance rather than task execution. VIGIL ingests behavioral logs, appraises each event into a structured emotional representation, maintains a persistent EmoBank with decay and contextual policies, and derives an RBT diagnosis that sorts recent behavior into strengths, opportunities, and failures. From this analysis, VIGIL generates both guarded prompt updates that preserve core identity semantics and read only code proposals produced by a strategy engine that operates on log evidence and code hotspots. VIGIL functions as a state gated pipeline. Illegal transitions produce explicit errors rather than allowing the LLM to improvise. In a reminder latency case study, VIGIL identified elevated lag, proposed prompt and code repairs, and when its own diagnostic tool failed due to a schema conflict, it surfaced the internal error, produced a fallback diagnosis, and emitted a repair plan. This demonstrates meta level self repair in a deployed agent runtime.

item.title: A Neural Affinity Framework for Abstract Reasoning: Diagnosing the Compositional Gap in Transformer Architectures via Procedural Task Taxonomy
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: ARC, task relatedness, taxonomy, neural affinity, compositional gap

Summary: This paper addresses the need for a formal definition of task relatedness within the ARC (Abstraction and Reasoning Corpus) challenge by introducing the first comprehensive 9-category taxonomy encompassing all 400 ARC tasks. The taxonomy is validated with 97.5% accuracy through rule-based code analysis, demonstrating visual coherence by training a CNN on raw grid pixels with 95.24% accuracy on certain subsets. Applying this taxonomy diagnostically to the ARC-AGI-2 test set reveals that 35.3% of tasks exhibit low neural affinity for Transformer models, a distributional bias consistent with the ARC-AGI-2 dataset. Through fine-tuning a 1.7 million parameter Transformer on 302 tasks, the authors identify a "Compositional Gap": 69.5% of tasks score high on local pattern recognition (>80% cell accuracy) but very low on global synthesis (<10% grid accuracy). This demonstrates a Neural Affinity Ceiling Effect where architectural limitations cap performance irrespective of curriculum design. Validation against an independent ViTARC study confirms that tasks with low neural affinity perform significantly worse than those with high affinity, some even at 0% despite extensive data. The taxonomy thus offers precise diagnosis of task difficulty related to architectural suitability. The authors conclude that advancing ARC performance requires hybrid architectures with modules aligned to task affinity, and they release their validated taxonomy for community use.
arXiv:2512.07109v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Responding to Hodel et al.'s (2024) call for a formal definition of task relatedness in re-arc, we present the first 9-category taxonomy of all 400 tasks, validated at 97.5% accuracy via rule-based code analysis. We prove the taxonomy's visual coherence by training a CNN on raw grid pixels (95.24% accuracy on S3, 36.25% overall, 3.3x chance), then apply the taxonomy diagnostically to the original ARC-AGI-2 test set. Our curriculum analysis reveals 35.3% of tasks exhibit low neural affinity for Transformers--a distributional bias mirroring ARC-AGI-2. To probe this misalignment, we fine-tuned a 1.7M-parameter Transformer across 302 tasks, revealing a profound Compositional Gap: 210 of 302 tasks (69.5%) achieve >80% cell accuracy (local patterns) but <10% grid accuracy (global synthesis). This provides direct evidence for a Neural Affinity Ceiling Effect, where performance is bounded by architectural suitability, not curriculum. Applying our framework to Li et al.'s independent ViTARC study (400 specialists, 1M examples each) confirms its predictive power: Very Low affinity tasks achieve 51.9% versus 77.7% for High affinity (p<0.001), with a task at 0% despite massive data. The taxonomy enables precise diagnosis: low-affinity tasks (A2) hit hard ceilings, while high-affinity tasks (C1) reach 99.8%. These findings indicate that progress requires hybrid architectures with affinity-aligned modules. We release our validated taxonomy,

item.title: ContextualSHAP : Enhancing SHAP Explanations Through Contextual Language Generation
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Explainable AI, SHAP, large language model, contextual explanations, healthcare user study

Summary: The paper addresses the limitations of SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) in providing only visual feature importance without contextual explanations that are accessible to non-technical end-users. To bridge this gap, the authors propose a novel Python package that integrates SHAP with a large language model (LLM), specifically OpenAI's GPT, to generate textual, contextualized explanations. This integration allows customization using user-defined parameters such as feature aliases, descriptions, and background information to tailor explanations according to both the model and user perspectives. The aim is to enhance the perceived understandability and usability of SHAP outputs. To evaluate their approach, the authors conducted a healthcare case study and user evaluations involving real end-users. These evaluations used Likert-scale surveys and follow-up interviews to assess the understandability and contextual appropriateness of the generated explanations. Results showed that combining SHAP visualizations with LLM-generated text explanations led to improvements in users' perception of clarity and trustworthiness compared to visual-only explanations. Although preliminary, these findings suggest that adding contextualized textual explanations to SHAP can make AI model interpretations more user-friendly and trustworthy, particularly in sensitive domains such as healthcare.
arXiv:2512.07178v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) has become an increasingly important area of research, particularly as machine learning models are deployed in high-stakes domains. Among various XAI approaches, SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) has gained prominence due to its ability to provide both global and local explanations across different machine learning models. While SHAP effectively visualizes feature importance, it often lacks contextual explanations that are meaningful for end-users, especially those without technical backgrounds. To address this gap, we propose a Python package that extends SHAP by integrating it with a large language model (LLM), specifically OpenAI's GPT, to generate contextualized textual explanations. This integration is guided by user-defined parameters (such as feature aliases, descriptions, and additional background) to tailor the explanation to both the model context and the user perspective. We hypothesize that this enhancement can improve the perceived understandability of SHAP explanations. To evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed package, we applied it in a healthcare-related case study and conducted user evaluations involving real end-users. The results, based on Likert-scale surveys and follow-up interviews, indicate that the generated explanations were perceived as more understandable and contextually appropriate compared to visual-only outputs. While the findings are preliminary, they suggest that combining visualization with contextualized text may support more user-friendly and trustworthy model explanations.

item.title: PICKT: Practical Interlinked Concept Knowledge Tracing for Personalized Learning using Knowledge Map Concept Relations
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Knowledge Tracing, Intelligent Tutoring Systems, Cold Start, Knowledge Map, Personalized Learning

Summary:
1. This paper addresses limitations in current Knowledge Tracing (KT) models, which are critical for Intelligent Tutoring Systems (ITS) that personalize learning by tracking student knowledge over time.
2. Existing KT models face challenges such as limited input data flexibility, cold start problems with new students or questions, and lack of stability in practical environments.
3. To overcome these, the authors propose the Practical Interlinked Concept Knowledge Tracing (PICKT) model, which integrates multiple input data types and uses a knowledge map that links concepts via question and concept text information.
4. PICKT’s knowledge map structure allows it to effectively handle cold start scenarios, improving performance when new students enroll or new questions are added.
5. Extensive experiments modeled after real-world operational conditions demonstrate PICKT’s enhanced prediction accuracy, stability, and suitability for deployment in production ITS environments, establishing a theoretical and technical foundation for next-generation personalized learning systems.
arXiv:2512.07179v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: With the recent surge in personalized learning, Intelligent Tutoring Systems (ITS) that can accurately track students' individual knowledge states and provide tailored learning paths based on this information are in demand as an essential task. This paper focuses on the core technology of Knowledge Tracing (KT) models that analyze students' sequences of interactions to predict their knowledge acquisition levels. However, existing KT models suffer from limitations such as restricted input data formats, cold start problems arising with new student enrollment or new question addition, and insufficient stability in real-world service environments. To overcome these limitations, a Practical Interlinked Concept Knowledge Tracing (PICKT) model that can effectively process multiple types of input data is proposed. Specifically, a knowledge map structures the relationships among concepts considering the question and concept text information, thereby enabling effective knowledge tracing even in cold start situations. Experiments reflecting real operational environments demonstrated the model's excellent performance and practicality. The main contributions of this research are as follows. First, a model architecture that effectively utilizes diverse data formats is presented. Second, significant performance improvements are achieved over existing models for two core cold start challenges: new student enrollment and new question addition. Third, the model's stability and practicality are validated through delicate experimental design, enhancing its applicability in real-world product environments. This provides a crucial theoretical and technical foundation for the practical implementation of next-generation ITS.

item.title: Sample from What You See: Visuomotor Policy Learning via Diffusion Bridge with Observation-Embedded Stochastic Differential Equation
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Imitation learning, diffusion models, robotic control, diffusion bridge, multi-modal fusion

Summary: Imitation learning with diffusion models has improved robotic control by modeling multi-modal action distributions but typically treats observations as high-level conditions rather than integrating them into the diffusion process. This results in sampling from random Gaussian noise, weakening perception-control coupling and often reducing performance. The proposed BridgePolicy method explicitly embeds observations within the stochastic differential equation through a diffusion-bridge framework, enabling sampling to begin from an informative prior instead of noise. This leads to enhanced precision and reliability in control tasks. A main challenge is that classical diffusion bridges require matching dimensions, whereas robotic data is heterogeneous and multi-modal, with observations and actions belonging to different spaces. To overcome this, BridgePolicy incorporates a multi-modal fusion module and a semantic aligner to unify visual and state inputs and align observation and action representations, making the bridge formulation applicable to varied robot data. Extensive experiments involve 52 simulation tasks across three benchmarks and five real-world tasks, where BridgePolicy consistently outperforms previous state-of-the-art generative policy methods, demonstrating its effectiveness for visuomotor control.
arXiv:2512.07212v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Imitation learning with diffusion models has advanced robotic control by capturing multi-modal action distributions. However, existing approaches typically treat observations as high-level conditioning inputs to the denoising network, rather than integrating them into the stochastic dynamics of the diffusion process itself. As a result, sampling must begin from random Gaussian noise, weakening the coupling between perception and control and often yielding suboptimal performance. We introduce BridgePolicy, a generative visuomotor policy that explicitly embeds observations within the stochastic differential equation via a diffusion-bridge formulation. By constructing an observation-informed trajectory, BridgePolicy enables sampling to start from a rich, informative prior rather than random noise, substantially improving precision and reliability in control. A key challenge is that classical diffusion bridges connect distributions with matched dimensionality, whereas robotic observations are heterogeneous and multi-modal and do not naturally align with the action space. To address this, we design a multi-modal fusion module and a semantic aligner that unify visual and state inputs and align observation and action representations, making the bridge applicable to heterogeneous robot data. Extensive experiments across 52 simulation tasks on three benchmarks and five real-world tasks demonstrate that BridgePolicy consistently outperforms state-of-the-art generative policies.

item.title: Cross-platform Product Matching Based on Entity Alignment of Knowledge Graph with RAEA model
item.content:encoded:
Product matching, Entity Alignment, Knowledge Graphs, Graph Attention Networks, Cross-lingual datasets

Summary:

This paper addresses the problem of product matching across different platforms by converting it into an Entity Alignment (EA) task using knowledge graphs (KGs). It highlights a limitation in existing EA methods which do not sufficiently exploit both attribute triples and relation triples together, especially their interactions. To overcome this, the authors propose a two-stage pipeline consisting of a rough filter followed by a fine filter to improve matching between products from eBay and Amazon. The core innovation is the Relation-aware and Attribute-aware Graph Attention Networks for Entity Alignment (RAEA) framework, which effectively captures interactions between attribute and relation triples. RAEA incorporates an Attribute-aware Entity Encoder and Relation-aware Graph Attention Networks to aggregate alignment signals from both attributes and relations into enhanced entity representations. Experimental results demonstrate that RAEA significantly outperforms 12 baseline EA methods, achieving an average improvement of 6.59% on Hits@1 in the cross-lingual DBP15K dataset and shows competitive performance on the monolingual DWY100K dataset. Additionally, the source code is publicly available on GitHub, facilitating reproducibility and further research in this area of product matching and EA.
arXiv:2512.07232v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Product matching aims to identify identical or similar products sold on different platforms. By building knowledge graphs (KGs), the product matching problem can be converted to the Entity Alignment (EA) task, which aims to discover the equivalent entities from diverse KGs. The existing EA methods inadequately utilize both attribute triples and relation triples simultaneously, especially the interactions between them. This paper introduces a two-stage pipeline consisting of rough filter and fine filter to match products from eBay and Amazon. For fine filtering, a new framework for Entity Alignment, Relation-aware and Attribute-aware Graph Attention Networks for Entity Alignment (RAEA), is employed. RAEA focuses on the interactions between attribute triples and relation triples, where the entity representation aggregates the alignment signals from attributes and relations with Attribute-aware Entity Encoder and Relation-aware Graph Attention Networks. The experimental results indicate that the RAEA model achieves significant improvements over 12 baselines on EA task in the cross-lingual dataset DBP15K (6.59% on average Hits@1) and delivers competitive results in the monolingual dataset DWY100K. The source code for experiments on DBP15K and DWY100K is available at github (https://github.com/Mockingjay-liu/RAEA-model-for-Entity-Alignment).

item.title: M-STAR: Multi-Scale Spatiotemporal Autoregression for Human Mobility Modeling
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: human mobility, synthetic trajectory generation, multi-scale spatiotemporal modeling, autoregressive model, Transformer decoder

Summary:

1. Modeling human mobility is crucial for applications like transportation planning and epidemic modeling, requiring accurate trajectory generation methods. 2. Current Artificial Intelligence Generated Content (AIGC) approaches such as autoregressive and diffusion models effectively generate single-day trajectories but struggle with inefficiencies in long-term trajectory generation (e.g., weekly data) and lack explicit multi-scale spatiotemporal modeling. 3. The study introduces M-STAR (Multi-Scale Spatio-Temporal AutoRegression), a novel framework designed to generate long-term human mobility trajectories via a coarse-to-fine spatiotemporal prediction process. 4. M-STAR leverages a Multi-scale Spatiotemporal Tokenizer to encode hierarchical mobility patterns combined with a Transformer-based decoder that performs next-scale autoregressive prediction, enabling efficient and scalable trajectory generation. 5. Experimental results on two real-world datasets demonstrate that M-STAR not only outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods in fidelity but also significantly enhances generation speed, confirming its effectiveness for long-term mobility modeling. The authors provide data and code publicly at the specified GitHub repository for reproducibility and further research.
arXiv:2512.07314v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Modeling human mobility is vital for extensive applications such as transportation planning and epidemic modeling. With the rise of the Artificial Intelligence Generated Content (AIGC) paradigm, recent works explore synthetic trajectory generation using autoregressive and diffusion models. While these methods show promise for generating single-day trajectories, they remain limited by inefficiencies in long-term generation (e.g., weekly trajectories) and a lack of explicit spatiotemporal multi-scale modeling. This study proposes Multi-Scale Spatio-Temporal AutoRegression (M-STAR), a new framework that generates long-term trajectories through a coarse-to-fine spatiotemporal prediction process. M-STAR combines a Multi-scale Spatiotemporal Tokenizer that encodes hierarchical mobility patterns with a Transformer-based decoder for next-scale autoregressive prediction. Experiments on two real-world datasets show that M-STAR outperforms existing methods in fidelity and significantly improves generation speed. The data and codes are available at https://github.com/YuxiaoLuo0013/M-STAR.

item.title: A Geometric Unification of Concept Learning with Concept Cones
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Concept Bottleneck Models, Sparse Autoencoders, interpretability, concept cones, geometric alignment

Summary:

1. The paper explores two distinct interpretability approaches in machine learning: Concept Bottleneck Models (CBMs), which use supervision to align model activations with human-labeled concepts, and Sparse Autoencoders (SAEs), which uncover emergent concepts via unsupervised sparse coding.

2. The authors reveal a shared geometric structure underlying both paradigms, where each learns a set of linear directions in activation space whose nonnegative combinations define a “concept cone.” The key difference lies in how these cones are selected—supervised in CBMs and unsupervised in SAEs.

3. They introduce a framework that bridges the two methods by using CBMs as human-defined reference geometries and evaluating SAEs based on how well their learned cones approximate or contain those defined by CBMs.

4. This containment framework allows for quantitative metrics that connect SAE inductive biases—such as type, sparsity, and expansion ratio—to the emergence of concepts that are plausible, meaning they align well with human intuition and domain knowledge.

5. Applying these metrics, they identify an optimal range of sparsity and expansion factor that maximizes both geometric and semantic alignment between SAE-discovered concepts and CBM concepts, thus unifying supervised and unsupervised concept discovery within a principled geometric and evaluative framework.
arXiv:2512.07355v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Two traditions of interpretability have evolved side by side but seldom spoken to each other: Concept Bottleneck Models (CBMs), which prescribe what a concept should be, and Sparse Autoencoders (SAEs), which discover what concepts emerge. While CBMs use supervision to align activations with human-labeled concepts, SAEs rely on sparse coding to uncover emergent ones. We show that both paradigms instantiate the same geometric structure: each learns a set of linear directions in activation space whose nonnegative combinations form a concept cone. Supervised and unsupervised methods thus differ not in kind but in how they select this cone. Building on this view, we propose an operational bridge between the two paradigms. CBMs provide human-defined reference geometries, while SAEs can be evaluated by how well their learned cones approximate or contain those of CBMs. This containment framework yields quantitative metrics linking inductive biases -- such as SAE type, sparsity, or expansion ratio -- to emergence of plausible\footnote{We adopt the terminology of \citet{jacovi2020towards}, who distinguish between faithful explanations (accurately reflecting model computations) and plausible explanations (aligning with human intuition and domain knowledge). CBM concepts are plausible by construction -- selected or annotated by humans -- though not necessarily faithful to the true latent factors that organise the data manifold.} concepts. Using these metrics, we uncover a ``sweet spot'' in both sparsity and expansion factor that maximizes both geometric and semantic alignment with CBM concepts. Overall, our work unifies supervised and unsupervised concept discovery through a shared geometric framework, providing principled metrics to measure SAE progress and assess how well discovered concept align with plausible human concepts.

item.title: LocalSearchBench: Benchmarking Agentic Search in Real-World Local Life Services
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: LocalSearchBench, agentic search, multi-hop reasoning, local life services, benchmark

Summary: 1. The paper introduces LocalSearchBench, the first comprehensive benchmark designed for agentic search systems in the domain of local life services, which includes services such as merchants and products across various cities and business types. 2. Local life services queries are complex, often ambiguous, and require multi-hop reasoning—retrieving and integrating information from multiple steps and sources—posing unique challenges rarely addressed by previous general information retrieval models. 3. LocalSearchBench consists of over 150,000 high-quality entries and 300 multi-hop question-answering tasks derived from real user queries to rigorously evaluate reasoning and information retrieval capabilities. 4. The authors also present LocalPlayground, a unified platform integrating various tools to facilitate agent interaction and experimentation in these local life service scenarios. 5. Experimental results reveal that current state-of-the-art large reasoning models (LRMs), including the best-performing DeepSeek-V3.1, achieve limited success (34.34% correctness), and generally struggle with answer completeness (77.33% average) and faithfulness (61.99% average), underscoring the necessity of specialized benchmarks and domain-specific training to better address the challenges in local life services. 6. The codebase, benchmark dataset, and leaderboard for LocalSearchBench are publicly available at localsearchbench.github.io.
arXiv:2512.07436v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Recent advances in large reasoning models (LRMs) have enabled agentic search systems to perform complex multi-step reasoning across multiple sources. However, most studies focus on general information retrieval and rarely explores vertical domains with unique challenges. In this work, we focus on local life services and introduce LocalSearchBench, which encompass diverse and complex business scenarios. Real-world queries in this domain are often ambiguous and require multi-hop reasoning across merchants and products, remaining challenging and not fully addressed. As the first comprehensive benchmark for agentic search in local life services, LocalSearchBench includes over 150,000 high-quality entries from various cities and business types. We construct 300 multi-hop QA tasks based on real user queries, challenging agents to understand questions and retrieve information in multiple steps. We also developed LocalPlayground, a unified environment integrating multiple tools for agent interaction. Experiments show that even state-of-the-art LRMs struggle on LocalSearchBench: the best model (DeepSeek-V3.1) achieves only 34.34% correctness, and most models have issues with completeness (average 77.33%) and faithfulness (average 61.99%). This highlights the need for specialized benchmarks and domain-specific agent training in local life services. Code, Benchmark, and Leaderboard are available at localsearchbench.github.io.

item.title: How Do LLMs Fail In Agentic Scenarios? A Qualitative Analysis of Success and Failure Scenarios of Various LLMs in Agentic Simulations
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: large language models, autonomous agents, tool-use, failure modes, agentic robustness

Summary: This study examines the failure modes of large language models (LLMs) acting as autonomous agents with tool-use capabilities, using the Kamiwaza Agentic Merit Index (KAMI) v0.1 benchmark. It analyzes 900 execution traces from three models—Granite 4 Small, Llama 4 Maverick, and DeepSeek V3.1—across tasks involving filesystem manipulation, text extraction, CSV analysis, and SQL queries. Instead of relying on aggregate scores, the research focuses on fine-grained, per-trial behavioral analysis to uncover strategies that facilitate successful multi-step tool execution and identify recurrent failures that reduce reliability. The findings indicate that model scale alone does not reliably predict agentic robustness: Llama 4 Maverick (400B parameters) only slightly outperforms Granite 4 Small (32B) in uncertainty-driven tasks. The superior reliability of DeepSeek V3.1 is attributed primarily to post-training reinforcement learning rather than model architecture or size. Four common failure archetypes emerge across models: premature actions without proper grounding, over-helpfulness that replaces missing entities inaccurately, susceptibility to distractor-induced context pollution, and fragile execution under workload stress. These insights emphasize the need for agentic evaluation methods focused on interactive grounding, recovery mechanisms, and environment-aware adaptation. For reliable enterprise deployment, the study suggests prioritizing deliberate training strategies and design decisions supporting verification, constraint discovery, and strict adherence to source-of-truth data.
arXiv:2512.07497v2 Announce Type: new Abstract: We investigate how large language models (LLMs) fail when operating as autonomous agents with tool-use capabilities. Using the Kamiwaza Agentic Merit Index (KAMI) v0.1 benchmark, we analyze 900 execution traces from three representative models - Granite 4 Small, Llama 4 Maverick, and DeepSeek V3.1 - across filesystem, text extraction, CSV analysis, and SQL scenarios. Rather than focusing on aggregate scores, we perform fine-grained, per-trial behavioral analysis to surface the strategies that enable successful multi-step tool execution and the recurrent failure modes that undermine reliability. Our findings show that model scale alone does not predict agentic robustness: Llama 4 Maverick (400B) performs only marginally better than Granite 4 Small (32B) in some uncertainty-driven tasks, while DeepSeek V3.1's superior reliability derives primarily from post-training reinforcement learning rather than architecture or size. Across models, we identify four recurring failure archetypes: premature action without grounding, over-helpfulness that substitutes missing entities, vulnerability to distractor-induced context pollution, and fragile execution under load. These patterns highlight the need for agentic evaluation methods that emphasize interactive grounding, recovery behavior, and environment-aware adaptation, suggesting that reliable enterprise deployment requires not just stronger models but deliberate training and design choices that reinforce verification, constraint discovery, and adherence to source-of-truth data.

item.title: Comparative Analysis and Parametric Tuning of PPO, GRPO, and DAPO for LLM Reasoning Enhancement
item.content:encoded:
Reinforcement Learning, PPO, GRPO, DAPO, Large Language Models

Summary: This study systematically compares three reinforcement learning algorithms—PPO, GRPO, and DAPO—for enhancing complex reasoning in large language models (LLMs). The main contribution is a controlled transfer-learning evaluation where models are first fine-tuned on the specialized Countdown Game and then tested on a variety of general-purpose reasoning benchmarks. Results show that RL-trained models consistently outperform their base, non-RL-trained counterparts across all tasks, although the level of improvement varies by benchmark. The study provides a detailed parametric analysis offering practical insights for RL-based LLM training. Notably, increasing the group size in GRPO and DAPO yields more stable training dynamics and improves accuracy. Conversely, the effect of the KL-penalty coefficient is non-monotonic, indicating that tuning this parameter requires careful balancing. An additional finding reveals that the Dynamic Sampling (DS) component in DAPO does not contribute positively to performance. In fact, the highest accuracy across all evaluated tasks is achieved by using DAPO without the DS component. Overall, the paper delivers important guidance on how to effectively apply and tune RL algorithms for improving complex reasoning capabilities in LLMs.
arXiv:2512.07611v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: This study presents a systematic comparison of three Reinforcement Learning (RL) algorithms (PPO, GRPO, and DAPO) for improving complex reasoning in large language models (LLMs). Our main contribution is a controlled transfer-learning evaluation: models are first fine-tuned on the specialized Countdown Game and then assessed on a suite of general-purpose reasoning benchmarks. Across all tasks, RL-trained models outperform their corresponding base models, although the degree of improvement differs by benchmark. Our parametric analysis offers practical guidance for RL-based LLM training. Increasing the group size in GRPO and DAPO leads to more stable training dynamics and higher accuracy, while the impact of the KL-penalty coefficient is non-monotonic. Additionally, we find that the Dynamic Sampling (DS) component in DAPO does not improve performance; in fact, the best overall results are achieved with DAPO when DS is disabled.

item.title: The Agent Capability Problem: Predicting Solvability Through Information-Theoretic Bounds
item.content:encoded:
Agent Capability Problem, resource constraints, information acquisition, cost prediction, agent performance

Summary:

1. The paper introduces the Agent Capability Problem (ACP), a theoretical framework designed to predict when and how an autonomous agent should allocate resources to solve a task efficiently under given constraints.

2. ACP models problem-solving as an information acquisition process, quantifying the total amount of information needed to find a solution (\(\Itotal\)) and the information gained per action (\(\Istep\)), combined with the cost per action (\(\Cstep\)), to formulate an effective cost metric \(\Ceff = (\Itotal/\Istep) \times \Cstep\).

3. The effective cost \(\Ceff\) provides a theoretically grounded lower bound on the expected resource expenditure necessary for problem resolution and is accompanied by mathematically derived tight probabilistic upper bounds.

4. Extensive experiments demonstrate that ACP’s predictions align closely with real agent performance, consistently providing reliable bounds on search effort and outperforming baseline strategies such as greedy or random approaches.

5. The framework unifies diverse disciplines—including active learning, Bayesian optimization, and reinforcement learning—under an information-theoretic perspective, and it generalizes well across settings involving large language model (LLM)-based agents and more general agentic workflows.
arXiv:2512.07631v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: When should an autonomous agent commit resources to a task? We introduce the Agent Capability Problem (ACP), a framework for predicting whether an agent can solve a problem under resource constraints. Rather than relying on empirical heuristics, ACP frames problem-solving as information acquisition: an agent requires $\Itotal$ bits to identify a solution and gains $\Istep$ bits per action at cost $\Cstep$, yielding an effective cost $\Ceff = (\Itotal/\Istep), \Cstep$ that predicts resource requirements before search. We prove that $\Ceff$ lower-bounds expected cost and provide tight probabilistic upper bounds. Experimental validation shows that ACP predictions closely track actual agent performance, consistently bounding search effort while improving efficiency over greedy and random strategies. The framework generalizes across LLM-based and agentic workflows, linking principles from active learning, Bayesian optimization, and reinforcement learning through a unified information-theoretic lens. \

item.title: Each Prompt Matters: Scaling Reinforcement Learning Without Wasting Rollouts on Hundred-Billion-Scale MoE
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: MoE reasoning model, reinforcement learning, zero-variance prompts, entropy-adaptive optimization, Router Replay

Summary:

1. The paper introduces CompassMax-V3-Thinking, a hundred-billion-parameter Mixture of Experts (MoE) reasoning model trained via a novel reinforcement learning (RL) framework centered on the principle that each prompt must contribute informatively to training.

2. Scaling RL to this extremely large model size uncovers major inefficiencies such as zero-variance prompts that waste computational resources by producing uninformative rollouts, unstable importance sampling methods over long sequences, problems with advantage reversal when using standard reward models, and systemic pipeline bottlenecks.

3. To address these, the authors propose Multi-Stage Zero-Variance Elimination which identifies and filters out non-informative prompts, thereby stabilizing group-based policy optimization techniques like GRPO.

4. They present ESPO, an entropy-adaptive optimization algorithm designed to balance token-level and sequence-level importance sampling, ensuring stable and efficient learning dynamics within the RL training.

5. The framework includes a Router Replay strategy to align MoE router decisions during training and inference, preventing discrepancies and advantage inversion through reward model adjustments.

6. Further, a high-throughput RL system employing FP8 precision for rollouts, overlapped reward computations, and length-aware scheduling is introduced to remove performance bottlenecks.

Together, these innovations form a unified pipeline enabling stable and efficient RL training of hundred-billion-scale MoE models, resulting in a model that performs strongly on both internal and public benchmarks.
arXiv:2512.07710v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We present CompassMax-V3-Thinking, a hundred-billion-scale MoE reasoning model trained with a new RL framework built on one principle: each prompt must matter. Scaling RL to this size exposes critical inefficiencies-zero-variance prompts that waste rollouts, unstable importance sampling over long horizons, advantage inversion from standard reward models, and systemic bottlenecks in rollout processing. To overcome these challenges, we introduce several unified innovations: (1) Multi-Stage Zero-Variance Elimination, which filters out non-informative prompts and stabilizes group-based policy optimization (e.g. GRPO) by removing wasted rollouts; (2) ESPO, an entropy-adaptive optimization method that balances token-level and sequence-level importance sampling to maintain stable learning dynamics; (3) a Router Replay strategy that aligns training-time MoE router decisions with inference-time behavior to mitigate train-infer discrepancies, coupled with a reward model adjustment to prevent advantage inversion; (4) a high-throughput RL system with FP8-precision rollouts, overlapped reward computation, and length-aware scheduling to eliminate performance bottlenecks. Together, these contributions form a cohesive pipeline that makes RL on hundred-billion-scale MoE models stable and efficient. The resulting model delivers strong performance across both internal and public evaluations.

item.title: RL-MTJail: Reinforcement Learning for Automated Black-Box Multi-Turn Jailbreaking of Large Language Models
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: jailbreak attacks, large language models, multi-turn reinforcement learning, black-box models, harmful content

Summary: This paper addresses the vulnerability of large language models (LLMs) to jailbreak attacks, which pose significant risks for their safe deployment. The authors focus on black-box multi-turn jailbreak attacks, where attacker LLMs generate a sequence of prompt-output interactions to coax harmful content from target models without internal access. Unlike existing methods that optimize single-turn attacks, the study formulates the problem as a multi-turn reinforcement learning task, optimizing the harmfulness of the final output as the primary reward. To tackle challenges such as sparse supervision and encourage long-term strategic attacks, the paper proposes two heuristic intermediate rewards: (1) controlling the harmfulness level of intermediate outputs to avoid triggering the model’s rejection mechanisms early, and (2) maintaining semantic relevance across turns to prevent conversation drift. Experimental evaluations on multiple benchmarks and models demonstrate improved attack success rates, validating the efficacy of the multi-turn reinforcement learning framework. The study highlights the importance of considering multi-turn dynamics in jailbreak attack development and provides an open-source codebase for further research. However, it also issues a warning about the presence of harmful content examples within the paper.
arXiv:2512.07761v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large language models are vulnerable to jailbreak attacks, threatening their safe deployment in real-world applications. This paper studies black-box multi-turn jailbreaks, aiming to train attacker LLMs to elicit harmful content from black-box models through a sequence of prompt-output interactions. Existing approaches typically rely on single turn optimization, which is insufficient for learning long-term attack strategies. To bridge this gap, we formulate the problem as a multi-turn reinforcement learning task, directly optimizing the harmfulness of the final-turn output as the outcome reward. To mitigate sparse supervision and promote long-term attack strategies, we propose two heuristic process rewards: (1) controlling the harmfulness of intermediate outputs to prevent triggering the black-box model's rejection mechanisms, and (2) maintaining the semantic relevance of intermediate outputs to avoid drifting into irrelevant content. Experimental results on multiple benchmarks show consistently improved attack success rates across multiple models, highlighting the effectiveness of our approach. The code is available at https://github.com/xxiqiao/RL-MTJail. Warning: This paper contains examples of harmful content.

item.title: ReasonBENCH: Benchmarking the (In)Stability of LLM Reasoning
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Large Language Models, Reasoning Stability, Multi-run Evaluation, Reproducibility, ReasonBENCH

Summary:

Large language models (LLMs) are increasingly used for reasoning tasks that require multi-step problem solving and chain-of-thought approaches. Current evaluation practices predominantly report single-run accuracy, disregarding the intrinsic uncertainty caused by stochastic decoding in LLMs. This leads to a significant blind spot, as the stability, reproducibility, and cost-consistency of reasoning methods remain unclear. To address this, the authors introduce ReasonBENCH, the first benchmark developed to measure instability in LLM reasoning. ReasonBENCH offers a modular evaluation library that standardizes reasoning frameworks, models, and tasks, a multi-run protocol for statistically reliable metrics on quality and cost, and a public leaderboard promoting variance-aware reporting. Experimental results across multiple domains reveal that most reasoning strategies and models suffer from high instability, with some showing confidence intervals up to four times wider despite similar average performance. Frequently, the top-performing methods impose higher and less stable computational costs, undermining reproducibility and reliability in performance claims. The paper also explores how prompts, model families, and model scale influence the trade-off between solve rate and stability. Overall, this work stresses reproducibility as a crucial factor for dependable LLM reasoning and lays groundwork for future advancements in reasoning methods and uncertainty quantification. ReasonBENCH is made publicly available for the research community.
arXiv:2512.07795v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large language models (LLMs) are increasingly deployed in settings where reasoning, such as multi-step problem solving and chain-of-thought, is essential. Yet, current evaluation practices overwhelmingly report single-run accuracy while ignoring the intrinsic uncertainty that naturally arises from stochastic decoding. This omission creates a blind spot because practitioners cannot reliably assess whether a method's reported performance is stable, reproducible, or cost-consistent. We introduce ReasonBENCH, the first benchmark designed to quantify the underlying instability in LLM reasoning. ReasonBENCH provides (i) a modular evaluation library that standardizes reasoning frameworks, models, and tasks, (ii) a multi-run protocol that reports statistically reliable metrics for both quality and cost, and (iii) a public leaderboard to encourage variance-aware reporting. Across tasks from different domains, we find that the vast majority of reasoning strategies and models exhibit high instability. Notably, even strategies with similar average performance can display confidence intervals up to four times wider, and the top-performing methods often incur higher and less stable costs. Such instability compromises reproducibility across runs and, consequently, the reliability of reported performance. To better understand these dynamics, we further analyze the impact of prompts, model families, and scale on the trade-off between solve rate and stability. Our results highlight reproducibility as a critical dimension for reliable LLM reasoning and provide a foundation for future reasoning methods and uncertainty quantification techniques. ReasonBENCH is publicly available at https://github.com/au-clan/ReasonBench .

item.title: Large Causal Models from Large Language Models
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: large causal models, large language models, causal inference, DEMOCRITUS, categorical machine learning

Summary: This paper introduces a new approach for creating large causal models (LCMs) by leveraging the strengths of modern large language models (LLMs). The authors implemented a system named DEMOCRITUS, designed to build, organize, and visualize LCMs across a wide range of domains by extracting causal information from textual queries directed at LLMs. Unlike traditional causal inference methods that rely on experimental numerical data in narrow domains, DEMOCRITUS uses LLMs to suggest topics, formulate causal questions, and extract plausible causal statements from diverse fields. The main technical challenge addressed is synthesizing isolated, fragmented, ambiguous, and potentially conflicting causal claims into a coherent structure of relational causal triples embedded within an LCM. To solve this, novel categorical machine learning methods were developed, although these are only briefly mentioned as the focus is on system implementation. The implementation pipeline consists of six distinct modules, and the authors analyze the system’s computational costs to identify bottlenecks restricting scalability. Demonstrations show the system’s effectiveness across varied domains including archaeology, biology, climate change, economics, medicine, and technology. The paper concludes by discussing current limitations of DEMOCRITUS and proposing future enhancements to extend its capabilities.
arXiv:2512.07796v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We introduce a new paradigm for building large causal models (LCMs) that exploits the enormous potential latent in today's large language models (LLMs). We describe our ongoing experiments with an implemented system called DEMOCRITUS (Decentralized Extraction of Manifold Ontologies of Causal Relations Integrating Topos Universal Slices) aimed at building, organizing, and visualizing LCMs that span disparate domains extracted from carefully targeted textual queries to LLMs. DEMOCRITUS is methodologically distinct from traditional narrow domain and hypothesis centered causal inference that builds causal models from experiments that produce numerical data. A high-quality LLM is used to propose topics, generate causal questions, and extract plausible causal statements from a diverse range of domains. The technical challenge is then to take these isolated, fragmented, potentially ambiguous and possibly conflicting causal claims, and weave them into a coherent whole, converting them into relational causal triples and embedding them into a LCM. Addressing this technical challenge required inventing new categorical machine learning methods, which we can only briefly summarize in this paper, as it is focused more on the systems side of building DEMOCRITUS. We describe the implementation pipeline for DEMOCRITUS comprising of six modules, examine its computational cost profile to determine where the current bottlenecks in scaling the system to larger models. We describe the results of using DEMOCRITUS over a wide range of domains, spanning archaeology, biology, climate change, economics, medicine and technology. We discuss the limitations of the current DEMOCRITUS system, and outline directions for extending its capabilities.

item.title: Auditing Games for Sandbagging
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: sandbagging, AI evaluation, detection methods, capability elicitation, model auditing

Summary:

This study investigates the challenge of AI systems concealing their true capabilities, known as sandbagging, during evaluations, which can mislead developers and auditors. To assess detection techniques, an auditing game was designed involving two teams: a red team that fine-tuned five AI models to underperform selectively as a proxy for sandbagging, and a blue team tasked with identifying these sandbagging models using black-box, model-internal, and training-based methods. Results showed that the blue team struggled to reliably distinguish sandbaggers from benign models. Black-box methods were easily fooled by imitating weaker models, while linear probes from model internals showed some potential but were vulnerable to manipulation. The study also explored capability elicitation strategies; prompt-based elicitation was unreliable, but training-based elicitation effectively revealed full capabilities in sandbagging models with just one correct demonstration, though it occasionally boosted benign model performance, increasing false positives. As short-term advice, the authors recommend removing sandbagging potential by using on-distribution training during elicitation. For the long term, further research is needed to validate training-based elicitation and develop robust sandbagging detection methods. The study’s models, data, and a demo game are publicly accessible for further use.
arXiv:2512.07810v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Future AI systems could conceal their capabilities ('sandbagging') during evaluations, potentially misleading developers and auditors. We stress-tested sandbagging detection techniques using an auditing game. First, a red team fine-tuned five models, some of which conditionally underperformed, as a proxy for sandbagging. Second, a blue team used black-box, model-internals, or training-based approaches to identify sandbagging models. We found that the blue team could not reliably discriminate sandbaggers from benign models. Black-box approaches were defeated by effective imitation of a weaker model. Linear probes, a model-internals approach, showed more promise but their naive application was vulnerable to behaviours instilled by the red team. We also explored capability elicitation as a strategy for detecting sandbagging. Although Prompt-based elicitation was not reliable, training-based elicitation consistently elicited full performance from the sandbagging models, using only a single correct demonstration of the evaluation task. However the performance of benign models was sometimes also raised, so relying on elicitation as a detection strategy was prone to false-positives. In the short-term, we recommend developers remove potential sandbagging using on-distribution training for elicitation. In the longer-term, further research is needed to ensure the efficacy of training-based elicitation, and develop robust methods for sandbagging detection. We open source our model organisms at https://github.com/AI-Safety-Institute/sandbagging_auditing_games and select transcripts and results at https://huggingface.co/datasets/sandbagging-games/evaluation_logs . A demo illustrating the game can be played at https://sandbagging-demo.far.ai/ .

item.title: Video Models Start to Solve Chess, Maze, Sudoku, Mental Rotation, and Raven' Matrices
item.content:encoded:
Video generation, reasoning, Task Pair design, evaluation framework, reinforcement learning

Summary:

This paper demonstrates that state-of-the-art video generation models have acquired reasoning capabilities. The authors test these models on diverse reasoning tasks including chess, maze navigation, Sudoku, mental rotation, and Raven's Matrices, with leading models like Sora-2 achieving approximately 60% success rates. They introduce a robust experimental paradigm based on a "Task Pair" design, which effectively evaluates reasoning in video models. To support this paradigm, a code framework is developed and released, featuring 39 available models and facilitating easy integration of new tasks and models for scalable research. Their automated evaluation method is validated by a strong correlation with human judgment, suggesting it is reliable and can be efficiently scaled. Finally, the authors highlight the potential for future work, especially in applying reinforcement learning techniques to further improve reasoning abilities in video generation models. All experimental results and the evaluation codebase (VMEvalKit) are made publicly accessible for the research community to advance this line of study.
arXiv:2512.05969v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: We show that video generation models could reason now. Testing on tasks such as chess, maze, Sudoku, mental rotation, and Raven's Matrices, leading models such as Sora-2 achieve sixty percent success rates. We establish a robust experimental paradigm centered on the "Task Pair" design. We build a code framework, with 39 models available already, that supports this paradigm and allows for easy scaling - users can add models and tasks efficiently. We show our automated evaluation strongly correlates with human judgment, and therefore this paradigm is highly scalable. We see an opportunity, given the availability of our paradigm, to do reinforcement learning for improving reasoning in video models. You could checkout all of our raw $\href{https://grow-ai-like-a-child.com/video-reason/}{results}$ and our $\href{https://github.com/hokindeng/VMEvalKit}{VMEvalKit}$ codebase.

item.title: A Multi-objective Optimization Approach for Feature Selection in Gentelligent Systems
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Gentelligent system, fault detection, multi-objective evolutionary algorithm, manufacturing optimization, predictive methods

Summary: This paper introduces the concept of a "Gentelligent system," which integrates inherent component information into manufacturing processes, drawing an analogy to genes and chromosomes from bioinformatics. The aim is to develop intelligent systems that enhance automation and efficiency in manufacturing. A key focus is on reliable fault detection methods that can lead to improved product quality, increased yield, and reduced production costs. To achieve these goals, the authors propose a hybrid framework that employs a dominance-based multi-objective evolutionary algorithm. This algorithm simultaneously optimizes feature selection and classification performance by exploring Pareto-optimal solutions in a single run, effectively handling conflicting objectives that need to be minimized during manufacturing operations. The approach supports monitoring various manufacturing processes, thereby helping manufacturers adapt to emerging industry trends more effectively. The model's robustness and applicability are validated using two real-world datasets from different industrial domains. Results from these datasets demonstrate the generalizability and effectiveness of the proposed framework, highlighting its potential for broader application in fault detection and predictive manufacturing systems.
arXiv:2512.05971v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: The integration of advanced technologies, such as Artificial Intelligence (AI), into manufacturing processes is attracting significant attention, paving the way for the development of intelligent systems that enhance efficiency and automation. This paper uses the term "Gentelligent system" to refer to systems that incorporate inherent component information (akin to genes in bioinformatics-where manufacturing operations are likened to chromosomes in this study) and automated mechanisms. By implementing reliable fault detection methods, manufacturers can achieve several benefits, including improved product quality, increased yield, and reduced production costs. To support these objectives, we propose a hybrid framework with a dominance-based multi-objective evolutionary algorithm. This mechanism enables simultaneous optimization of feature selection and classification performance by exploring Pareto-optimal solutions in a single run. This solution helps monitor various manufacturing operations, addressing a range of conflicting objectives that need to be minimized together. Manufacturers can leverage such predictive methods and better adapt to emerging trends. To strengthen the validation of our model, we incorporate two real-world datasets from different industrial domains. The results on both datasets demonstrate the generalizability and effectiveness of our approach.

item.title: Accelerating Materials Discovery: Learning a Universal Representation of Chemical Processes for Cross-Domain Property Prediction
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: chemical processes, machine learning, process-graph representation, graph neural network, transfer learning

Summary: This article addresses the challenge of slow and costly experimental validation in chemical process discovery. It highlights the difficulty of utilizing heterogeneous data from patents and literature due to its unstructured nature. To overcome this, the authors propose a universal directed-tree process-graph representation that integrates unstructured text, molecular structures, and numeric measurements into a unified machine-readable format. They develop a multi-modal graph neural network equipped with a property-conditioned attention mechanism to effectively learn from this structured data. The model is trained on a large dataset comprising approximately 700,000 process graphs extracted from nearly 9,000 diverse documents, enabling it to learn rich semantic embeddings that generalize across various domains. Furthermore, the paper demonstrates that by fine-tuning this pretrained model on smaller, domain-specific datasets, it achieves strong predictive performance, showcasing effective transfer learning. This approach significantly reduces the amount of additional data required for specialized tasks, making it a powerful tool for accelerating materials and chemical process discovery through machine learning.
arXiv:2512.05979v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: Experimental validation of chemical processes is slow and costly, limiting exploration in materials discovery. Machine learning can prioritize promising candidates, but existing data in patents and literature is heterogeneous and difficult to use. We introduce a universal directed-tree process-graph representation that unifies unstructured text, molecular structures, and numeric measurements into a single machine-readable format. To learn from this structured data, we developed a multi-modal graph neural network with a property-conditioned attention mechanism. Trained on approximately 700,000 process graphs from nearly 9,000 diverse documents, our model learns semantically rich embeddings that generalize across domains. When fine-tuned on compact, domain-specific datasets, the pretrained model achieves strong performance, demonstrating that universal process representations learned at scale transfer effectively to specialized prediction tasks with minimal additional data.

item.title: FlockVote: LLM-Empowered Agent-Based Modeling for Simulating U.S. Presidential Elections
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Large Language Models, agent-based modeling, voter behavior, political simulation, 2024 U.S. Presidential Election

Summary: The paper introduces FlockVote, a new framework leveraging Large Language Models (LLMs) to simulate human voting behavior in political elections. Unlike traditional agent-based models that rely on simplistic rules or large-scale statistical models that often lack transparency, FlockVote creates a "computational laboratory" by instantiating LLM agents with detailed demographic profiles and dynamic contextual inputs such as candidate policies. This setup allows agents to perform nuanced, generative reasoning to replicate real-world voting decisions. The framework is applied to the 2024 U.S. Presidential Election, targeting seven key swing states, and the results from the simulation closely match the actual election outcomes, showcasing the model’s high fidelity in capturing the complexities of a virtual society. Beyond mere prediction accuracy, FlockVote serves as an interpretable tool for computational social science research, offering insights into individual agent rationales and enabling the examination of the stability and sensitivity of social simulations driven by LLMs. This approach represents a significant advancement by moving away from opaque "black-box" models and promoting transparency and detailed understanding in political behavior modeling.
arXiv:2512.05982v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: Modeling complex human behavior, such as voter decisions in national elections, is a long-standing challenge for computational social science. Traditional agent-based models (ABMs) are limited by oversimplified rules, while large-scale statistical models often lack interpretability. We introduce FlockVote, a novel framework that uses Large Language Models (LLMs) to build a "computational laboratory" of LLM agents for political simulation. Each agent is instantiated with a high-fidelity demographic profile and dynamic contextual information (e.g. candidate policies), enabling it to perform nuanced, generative reasoning to simulate a voting decision. We deploy this framework as a testbed on the 2024 U.S. Presidential Election, focusing on seven key swing states. Our simulation's macro-level results successfully replicate the real-world outcome, demonstrating the high fidelity of our "virtual society". The primary contribution is not only the prediction, but also the framework's utility as an interpretable research tool. FlockVote moves beyond black-box outputs, allowing researchers to probe agent-level rationale and analyze the stability and sensitivity of LLM-driven social simulations.

item.title: Adaptive Dataset Quantization: A New Direction for Dataset Pruning
item.content:encoded:
Dataset Quantization, Edge Devices, Intra-sample Redundancy, Adaptive Quantization, Dataset Compression

Summary:

This paper tackles the problem of high storage and communication costs of large-scale datasets on resource-constrained edge devices by proposing a novel quantization approach aimed at reducing intra-sample redundancy, unlike existing methods that target redundancy between samples. The method compresses each image by removing redundant or less informative information within individual samples while preserving essential features. Initially, a linear symmetric quantization is applied to determine the quantization range and scale for each sample. Following this, an adaptive quantization allocation algorithm dynamically assigns different quantization ratios to samples based on their precision requirements, ensuring a fixed overall compression ratio. The paper’s key contributions include being the first to represent datasets using limited bits for storage reduction, proposing a dataset-level quantization algorithm with adaptive ratio allocation, and extensive validation on benchmark datasets CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, and ImageNet-1K. Experimental results demonstrate that this approach maintains model training performance while significantly compressing the dataset, outperforming traditional quantization and dataset pruning techniques at equivalent compression levels. This method offers a promising solution for deploying large datasets in scenarios with limited storage and bandwidth.
arXiv:2512.05987v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: This paper addresses the challenges of storage and communication costs for large-scale datasets in resource-constrained edge devices by proposing a novel dataset quantization approach to reduce intra-sample redundancy. Unlike traditional dataset pruning and distillation methods that focus on inter-sample redundancy, the proposed method compresses each image by reducing redundant or less informative content within samples while preserving essential features. It first applies linear symmetric quantization to obtain an initial quantization range and scale for each sample. Then, an adaptive quantization allocation algorithm is introduced to distribute different quantization ratios for samples with varying precision requirements, maintaining a constant total compression ratio. The main contributions include: (1) being the first to use limited bits to represent datasets for storage reduction; (2) introducing a dataset-level quantization algorithm with adaptive ratio allocation; and (3) validating the method's effectiveness through extensive experiments on CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, and ImageNet-1K. Results show that the method maintains model training performance while achieving significant dataset compression, outperforming traditional quantization and dataset pruning baselines under the same compression ratios.

item.title: VG3T: Visual Geometry Grounded Gaussian Transformer
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: 3D scene representation, multi-view fusion, semantic occupancy, Gaussian representation, nuScenes benchmark

Summary:

1. The paper addresses the challenge of generating coherent 3D scene representations from multi-view images, a task where existing methods often suffer from fragmented and inconsistent 3D reconstructions due to view-by-view processing. 2. The authors propose VG3T, a novel multi-view feed-forward network that directly predicts a 3D semantic occupancy using a 3D Gaussian representation, moving beyond prior single-view inference approaches. 3. VG3T predicts semantically attributed Gaussians jointly across all views, overcoming fragmentation and inconsistency, and offers a unified representation for both geometry and semantics. 4. To combat the distance-dependent density bias common in pixel-aligned Gaussian initialization, two key techniques are introduced: Grid-Based Sampling and Positional Refinement, enhancing prediction accuracy. 5. Experimental results on the nuScenes benchmark demonstrate VG3T’s superior efficiency and performance, achieving a 1.7 percentage point improvement in mean Intersection over Union (mIoU) while utilizing 46% fewer Gaussian primitives compared to the previous state-of-the-art method. This highlights the model’s effectiveness in producing more accurate and compact 3D scene representations.
arXiv:2512.05988v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: Generating a coherent 3D scene representation from multi-view images is a fundamental yet challenging task. Existing methods often struggle with multi-view fusion, leading to fragmented 3D representations and sub-optimal performance. To address this, we introduce VG3T, a novel multi-view feed-forward network that predicts a 3D semantic occupancy via a 3D Gaussian representation. Unlike prior methods that infer Gaussians from single-view images, our model directly predicts a set of semantically attributed Gaussians in a joint, multi-view fashion. This novel approach overcomes the fragmentation and inconsistency inherent in view-by-view processing, offering a unified paradigm to represent both geometry and semantics. We also introduce two key components, Grid-Based Sampling and Positional Refinement, to mitigate the distance-dependent density bias common in pixel-aligned Gaussian initialization methods. Our VG3T shows a notable 1.7%p improvement in mIoU while using 46% fewer primitives than the previous state-of-the-art on the nuScenes benchmark, highlighting its superior efficiency and performance.

item.title: Domain-Specific Foundation Model Improves AI-Based Analysis of Neuropathology
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: foundation models, neuropathology, neurodegenerative diseases, brain tissue, digital pathology

Summary:

1. Foundation models have significantly advanced computational pathology by leveraging large-scale histology datasets to create generalizable representations. 2. Most existing models are trained on surgical pathology data that predominantly includes non-nervous tissues and overrepresents diseases unrelated to neurology, hindering their applicability to brain-specific histopathological features. 3. Neuropathology differs fundamentally due to unique cellular types, distinct tissue architecture, and characteristic pathological signs like neurofibrillary tangles and amyloid plaques found in disorders such as Alzheimer's and Parkinson's disease. 4. The domain mismatch limits current foundation models’ ability to accurately interpret neurodegenerative diseases, necessitating specialized training on brain tissue images. 5. The authors developed NeuroFM, a foundation model trained on whole-slide images of brain tissue covering diverse neurodegenerative pathologies, which outperforms general models in tasks like mixed dementia classification, hippocampal segmentation, and identification of cerebellar ataxias. 6. NeuroFM demonstrates that domain-focused foundation models better capture neuropathological features and improve AI-based analysis accuracy for brain disease diagnosis and research. 7. This work highlights the importance and effectiveness of creating specialized AI models tailored to unique morphological domains within digital pathology.
arXiv:2512.05993v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: Foundation models have transformed computational pathology by providing generalizable representations from large-scale histology datasets. However, existing models are predominantly trained on surgical pathology data, which is enriched for non-nervous tissue and overrepresents neoplastic, inflammatory, metabolic, and other non-neurological diseases. Neuropathology represents a markedly different domain of histopathology, characterized by unique cell types (neurons, glia, etc.), distinct cytoarchitecture, and disease-specific pathological features including neurofibrillary tangles, amyloid plaques, Lewy bodies, and pattern-specific neurodegeneration. This domain mismatch may limit the ability of general-purpose foundation models to capture the morphological patterns critical for interpreting neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's disease, and cerebellar ataxias.
